Caption: Fig. 1. Our new method for visualizing genome rearrangements: deletions (green), inversions (brown), and inter-chromosomal translocations (cyan) classiﬁed from a cancer genome with respect to the reference human genome are depicted. Arcs drawn in the upper region of the display depict inter-chromosomal translocation relationships. A region-of-interest (grey window) is selected, highlighting translocations that intersect the region.
Fig. 2. An illustrated taxonomy of the genome rearrangements explored in this work.

Fig. 3. Circos visualization of genome rearrangements in a cancer genome, given in the style presented in [9]. Here, the outermost ring depicts chromosome numbering and cytogenetic bands. Deletions are given in green, inversions in yellow. Inter-chromosomal translocations are rendered with black arcs in the center of the display.

Fig. 4. Example of the multi-scale, linked perspectives, providing local details in context. At the top of the display is the global view of the entire genome. A sliding window rendered atop the global view deﬁnes the bounds for the region-of-interest view given below. Here, an inversion has been selected from the region-of-interest view and is shown in the rearrangement view at the bottom of the display. Gene copy number and cytogenetic bands are rendered below the region-of-interest view. In this case, according to the blue coloring, gene copy number is depicted to be low near the end of chromosome 4 and the start of chromosome 5. Additionally, overlapping inversions and deletions are indicated in the region-of-interest view. Greater widths of the arc glyphs indicates higher conﬁdence in the detection of the given rearrangement.

Table 1. Expected insight questions provided by participants of our study. If the visualization model enabled the insight, it is marked with an x, otherwise its entry is left blank. If both models enabled the insight, but participants suggested one model signiﬁcantly outperformed the other, it is marked with x+. The ﬁrst grouping, questions 1-6, relates to rearrangement features. The second grouping, questions 7-9, relates to conﬁdence and uncertainty in results, and the last grouping, questions 10 and 11, relates to comparative visualization.
Fig. 6. Insight per minute measures from each of the ﬁve participants. Each participant is colored uniquely. Circos results are denoted by cir- cles, while Gremlin results are denoted with triangles.

Fig. 5. Total insights from each of the ﬁve participants over the two data sets explored with each visualization model. Each participant is colored uniquely. Circos results are denoted by circles, while Gremlin results are denoted with triangles.
Fig. 8. Comparative visualizations using Circos and Gremlin, represen- tative of the strategies observed in user study evaluations.

Fig. 7. Total complexity-categorized insights from each of the ﬁve par- ticipants over the two data sets explored with each visualization model. Each participant is colored uniquely. Circos results are denoted by cir- cles, while Gremlin results are denoted with triangles.

Fig. 9. Comparative visual analysis approaches with radial and linear insights. mappings of the genome. The top row depicts strategies that emerged from our user studies. The bottom row offers scalable approaches for 10 C ONCLUSIONS comparing multiple genomes using each mapping type.
